claim: A woman with short hair is more intelligent.

supporting.text: Intelligence is not determined by physical appearance, including hair length.

attacks.text: Intelligence is not determined by physical appearance, including hair length.
Studies show a correlation between unconventional appearance (e.g., short hair in women) and higher education levels, which may indicate intelligence.
Correlation does not imply causation; education levels may be influenced by socioeconomic factors rather than appearance.
Societal stereotypes often associate short-haired women with professionalism and competence, which could influence perceptions of intelligence.
Perceptions are subjective and culturally dependent; they do not reflect objective measures of intelligence.

supporting.text: Hair length is a personal choice and has no correlation with cognitive abilities.

attacks.text: Hair length is a personal choice and has no correlation with cognitive abilities.

supporting.text: Scientific studies on intelligence do not identify hair length as a factor in intellectual capacity.
